articles.headline: Recalled Devices Mostly Untested, New Study Says
articles.snippet: Most devices involved in high-risk recalls were cleared in a process that required little, if any, testing.
articles.abstract: Most devices involved in high-risk recalls were cleared in a process that required little, if any, testing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most medical devices recalled in recent years by the Food and Drug Administration because they posed a high risk to patients were not rigorously studied before being cleared for sale, according to a study in a medical journal released Monday.

articles.headline: I.R.S. Takes on Tax Abuse by Charity Support Groups
articles.snippet: The Internal Revenue Service is cracking down on a category of tax-exempt organizations.
articles.abstract: The Internal Revenue Service is cracking down on a category of tax-exempt organizations.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last five years, the Internal Revenue Service has revoked the tax exemption of 72 groups, known as supporting organizations, that obscure philanthropies created to support specific charities.

articles.headline: Airlines Beat Storms by Canceling Ahead
articles.snippet: Severe storms and cautious airlines taking pre-emptive action have made this winter a bad one for travel.
articles.abstract: Severe storms and cautious airlines taking pre-emptive action have made this winter a bad one for travel.
articles.lead_paragraph: This has been a terrible winter for flying.

articles.headline: Police Departments Downsize, From 4 Legs to 2
articles.snippet: Budget-crunched police departments across the country are retiring their horses and closing their stables.
articles.abstract: Budget-crunched police departments across the country are retiring their horses and closing their stables.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — He was a 10-year veteran of the Charleston Police Department, specializing in patrolling this city’s palmetto-lined streets, improving community relations and keeping big crowds in check — until his unit was disbanded, a victim of budget cuts.

articles.headline: Companies Warn That Higher Prices Are Looming
articles.snippet: Many big companies, facing higher raw material costs, say they cannot hold off any longer and must raise prices.
articles.abstract: Many big companies, facing higher raw material costs, say they cannot hold off any longer and must raise prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: A package of Oscar Mayer cold cuts. A pair of Nine West boots. A Whirlpool washing machine.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford, Motoko Rich and William Neuman

articles.headline: To Stand Out, Retailers Flock to Exclusive Lines
articles.snippet: Department stores believe buyers are tired of the same things everywhere, and are signing exclusive contracts.
articles.abstract: Department stores believe buyers are tired of the same things everywhere, and are signing exclusive contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: To find Miley Cyrus’s line of clothes, shoppers head to Wal-Mart. For Selena Gomez’s, they go to Kmart. Jennifer Lopez’s line is at Kohl’s, and Demi Lovato’s at Target. Rachel Bilson dinnerware can only be found at Macy’s, while for the Kardashian Kollection, fans must go to Sears.

articles.headline: Bahrain Takes the Stage With a Raucous Protest
articles.snippet: More than 10,000 people streamed into Pearl Square as a political protest merged with a funeral procession in the Persian Gulf kingdom.
articles.abstract: More than 10,000 people streamed into Pearl Square as a political protest merged with a funeral procession in the Persian Gulf kingdom.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAMA, Bahrain  Thousands of protesters poured into this nation’s symbolic center, Pearl Square, late Tuesday in a raucous rally that again demonstrated the power of popular movements that are transforming the political landscape of the Middle East.

articles.headline: Russia Embraces Offshore Arctic Drilling
articles.snippet: Safety and environmental fears made the United States wary, but oil companies are eager to follow Russia in.
articles.abstract: Safety and environmental fears made the United States wary, but oil companies are eager to follow Russia in.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Arctic Ocean is a forbidding place for oil drillers. But that is not stopping Russia from jumping in — or Western oil companies from eagerly following.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Clifford Krauss
